q: What are the symptoms of atherosclerosis?
a: Symptoms can include chest pain, pain in the arms and legs, feeling short of breath, feeling tired all the time, feeling weak, and feeling confused.

q: How can I check if I have atherosclerosis?
a: You can get a free NHS health check if you're over 40, which can spot the early signs of heart disease and stroke, as well as kidney disease, dementia, and type 2 diabetes.

q: What increases the chances of getting atherosclerosis?
a: Factors that increase the chances of getting atherosclerosis include being over 65 years of age, smoking, having high cholesterol, having high blood pressure, and having close relatives with cardiovascular disease.

q: What can I do to help with atherosclerosis?
a: You can help stop atherosclerosis from getting worse by eating healthily, reducing saturated fat and sugar intake, exercising regularly, maintaining a healthy weight, and keeping blood sugar levels under control if you have diabetes.

q: What treatments are available for atherosclerosis?
a: There are currently no treatments to reverse atherosclerosis, but you may be offered medicines to lower your risk of heart attack or stroke, such as cholesterol-lowering and blood pressure-lowering medicines. Surgery may also be considered to improve blood flow through affected arteries.

q: What are the complications of atherosclerosis?
a: Without lifestyle changes and medical treatment, atherosclerosis may worsen over time and can lead to heart attacks, strokes, peripheral arterial disease, and other types of cardiovascular disease.

q: When should I seek immediate medical help for atherosclerosis?
a: You should call 999 if you experience signs of a heart attack, stroke, or difficulty breathing, such as chest pain, face dropping on one side, inability to hold both arms up, difficulty speaking, gasping for breath, sudden confusion, or sudden inability to think or speak clearly.

q: Can atherosclerosis be reversed?
a: There are currently no treatments to reverse atherosclerosis, but lifestyle changes and medication can help manage and reduce the risk of complications.

q: What is peripheral arterial disease?
a: Peripheral arterial disease is a complication of atherosclerosis that occurs when the arteries in the legs and feet become narrowed, leading to reduced blood flow and potential tissue damage.

q: How can I lower my risk of atherosclerosis?
a: You can lower your risk of atherosclerosis by making lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, eating a healthy diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising regularly, managing stress, and controlling other underlying health conditions.

q: What are the symptoms of atherosclerosis?
a: Symptoms of atherosclerosis may include chest pain, pain in arms and legs (especially during exercise), shortness of breath, fatigue, weakness, and confusion.

q: How can I check if I have atherosclerosis?
a: You may not have any symptoms of atherosclerosis, but if you are over 40 years old, you can get a free NHS health check to spot early signs. Otherwise, it is advised to consult a GP for a proper diagnosis.

q: What causes atherosclerosis?
a: Atherosclerosis occurs when fatty deposits build up in the arteries, causing them to narrow. Factors that increase the risk include age, smoking, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, and having close relatives with cardiovascular disease.

q: What can I do to help with atherosclerosis?
a: To help stop atherosclerosis from getting worse, you can make lifestyle changes such as maintaining a healthy diet, exercising regularly, maintaining a healthy weight, not smoking, and limiting alcohol consumption.

q: Are there treatments for atherosclerosis?
a: There are currently no treatments to reverse atherosclerosis, but you may be offered medications to lower your risk of heart attack or stroke. Medications may include statins to lower cholesterol, blood pressure medications, medications to prevent blood clots, and medications to control blood sugar levels if you have diabetes. In some cases, surgery may be needed to improve blood flow.

q: What are the complications of atherosclerosis?
a: If left untreated, atherosclerosis can lead to heart attacks, strokes, peripheral arterial disease, and other cardiovascular diseases.

q: When should I seek immediate medical attention?
a: You should call 999 if you experience signs of a heart attack, stroke, difficulty breathing, or sudden confusion.

q: Can lifestyle changes and medical treatment help with atherosclerosis?
a: Yes, lifestyle changes like diet and exercise, along with medical treatment, can help manage atherosclerosis and prevent it from worsening.

q: What can I expect during an NHS health check for atherosclerosis?
a: During an NHS health check, a healthcare professional may check your blood pressure, cholesterol, blood sugar levels, and discuss your lifestyle habits. They may also assess your risk of developing heart disease, stroke, kidney disease, dementia, and type 2 diabetes.

q: Is atherosclerosis preventable?
a: While atherosclerosis may not be entirely preventable, you can reduce your risk by adopting a healthy lifestyle, quitting smoking, eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, managing your blood pressure and cholesterol levels, and seeking regular medical check-ups.
